ol.li: Understand the basic properties of orthogonal complements.
Learn to compute the orthogonal complement of a subspace.
Recipes: shortcuts for computing the orthogonal complements of common subspaces.
Theorem: row rank equals column rank.

introduction.p: It will be important to compute the set of all vectors that are orthogonal to a given set of vectors. It turns out that a vector is orthogonal to a set of vectors if and only if it is orthogonal to the span of those vectors, which is a subspace, so we restrict ourselves to the case of subspaces.

subsection.title: Definition of the Orthogonal Complement
subsection.p: Taking the orthogonal complement is an operation that is performed on subspaces.

statement.p:
Let W be a subspace of \R^n. Its orthogonal complement is the subspace
W^\perp = \bigl\{ \text{$v$ in $\R^n$}\mid v\cdot w=0 \text{ for all $w$ in $W$} \bigr\}.
The symbol W^\perp is sometimes read W perp.

subsection.p: This is the set of all vectors v in \R^n that are orthogonal to all of the vectors in W. We will show below that W^\perp is indeed a subspace.

paragraphs.p: We see in the above pictures that (W^\perp)^\perp = W.

specialcase.p: The orthogonal complement of \R^n is \{0\}, since the zero vector is the only vector that is orthogonal to all of the vectors in \R^n.
For the same reason, we have \{0\}^\perp = \R^n.

subsection.title: Computing Orthogonal Complements
subsection.p: Since any subspace is a span, the following proposition gives a recipe for computing the orthogonal complement of any subspace. However, below we will give several shortcuts for computing the orthogonal complements of other common kinds of subspacesin particular, null spaces. To compute the orthogonal complement of a general subspace, usually it is best to rewrite the subspace as the column space or null space of a matrix, as in this .

proposition.title: The orthogonal complement of a column space

statement.p:
Let A be a matrix and let W=\Col(A). Then
W^\perp = \Nul(A^T).

solution.p:
According to the , we need to compute the null space of the matrix
\mat{1 7 2; -2 3 1} \;\xrightarrow{\text{RREF}}\; \mat{1 0 -1/17; 0 1 5/17}.
The free variable is x_3, so the parametric form of the solution set is x_1=x_3/17,\,x_2=-5x_3/17, and the parametric vector form is
\vec{x_1 x_2 x_3} = x_3\vec{1/17 -5/17 1}.
Scaling by a factor of 17, we see that
W^\perp = \Span\left\{\vec{1 -5 17}\right\}.
We can check our work:
\vec{1 7 2}\cdot\vec{1 -5 17} = 0 \qquad \vec{-2 3 1}\cdot\vec{1 -5 17} = 0.

statement.p: Find all vectors orthogonal to v = \vec{1 1 -1}.

solution.p: According to the , we need to compute the null space of the matrix A = \mat{\matrow{v}} = \mat{1 1 -1}. This matrix is in reduced-row echelon form. The parametric form for the solution set is x_1 = -x_2 + x_3, so the parametric vector form of the general solution is x = \vec{x_1 x_2 x_3} = x_2\vec{-1 1 0} + x_3\vec{1 0 1}. Therefore, the answer is the plane \Span\left\{\vec{-1 1 0},\;\vec{1 0 1}\right\}.

solution.p: According to the , we need to compute the null space of the matrix A = \mat{1 1 -1; 1 1 1}\;\xrightarrow{\text{RREF}}\;\mat{1 1 0; 0 0 1}. The parametric vector form of the solution is \vec{x_1 x_2 x_3} = x_2\vec{-1 1 0}. Therefore, the answer is the line \Span\left\{\vec{-1 1 0}\right\}.

subsection.p: In order to find shortcuts for computing orthogonal complements, we need the following basic facts. Looking back the the above examples, all of these facts should be believable.

statement.p:
Let W be a subspace of \R^n. Then:
W^\perp is also a subspace of \R^n.
(W^\perp)^\perp = W.
\dim(W) + \dim(W^\perp) = n.

proof.p:
For the first assertion, we verify the three defining properties of subspaces.
The zero vector is in W^\perp because the zero vector is orthogonal to every vector in \R^n.
Let u,v be in W^\perp, so u\cdot x = 0 and v\cdot x = 0 for every vector x in W. We must verify that (u+v)\cdot x = 0 for every x in W. Indeed, we have (u+v)\cdot x = u\cdot x + v\cdot x = 0 + 0 = 0.
Let u be in W^\perp, so u\cdot x = 0 for every x in W, and let c be a scalar. We must verify that (cu)\cdot x = 0 for every x in W. Indeed, we have (cu)\cdot x = c(u\cdot x) = c0 = 0.

Next we prove the third assertion. Let v_1,v_2,\ldots,v_m be a basis for W, so m = \dim(W), and let v_{m+1},v_{m+2},\ldots,v_k be a basis for W^\perp, so k-m = \dim(W^\perp). We need to show k=n. First we claim that \{v_1,v_2,\ldots,v_m,v_{m+1},v_{m+2},\ldots,v_k\} is linearly independent. Suppose that c_1v_1 + c_2v_2 + \cdots + c_kv_k = 0. Let w = c_1v_1 + c_2v_2 + \cdots + c_mv_m and w' = c_{m+1}v_{m+1} + c_{m+2}v_{m+2} + \cdots + c_kv_k, so w is in W, w' is in W', and w + w' = 0. Then w = -w' is in both W and W^\perp, which implies w is perpendicular to itself. In particular, w\cdot w = 0, so w = 0, and hence w' = 0. Therefore, all coefficients c_i are equal to zero, because \{v_1,v_2,\ldots,v_m\} and \{v_{m+1},v_{m+2},\ldots,v_k\} are linearly independent.

Finally, we prove the second assertion. Clearly W is contained in (W^\perp)^\perp: this says that everything in W is perpendicular to the set of all vectors perpendicular to everything in W. Let m=\dim(W). By 3, we have \dim(W^\perp) = n-m, so \dim((W^\perp)^\perp) = n - (n-m) = m. The only m-dimensional subspace of (W^\perp)^\perp is all of (W^\perp)^\perp, so (W^\perp)^\perp = W.

statement.p: The row space of a matrix A is the span of the rows of A, and is denoted \Row(A).

subsection.p: Row spaceis column space of transpose Column spaceis row space of transpose If A is an m\times n matrix, then the rows of A are vectors with n entries, so \Row(A) is a subspace of \R^n. Equivalently, since the rows of A are the columns of A^T, the row space of A is the column space of A^T: \Row(A) = \Col(A^T).

We showed in the above that if A has rows v_1^T,v_2^T,\ldots,v_m^T, then \Row(A)^\perp = \Span\{v_1,v_2,\ldots,v_m\}^\perp = \Nul(A). Taking orthogonal complements of both sides and using the second fact gives \Row(A) = \Nul(A)^\perp. Replacing A by A^T and remembering that \Row(A)=\Col(A^T) gives \Col(A)^\perp = \Nul(A^T) \sptxt{and} \Col(A) = \Nul(A^T)^\perp. To summarize:

bluebox.title: Recipes: Shortcuts for computing orthogonal complements

subsection.p: As mentioned in the beginning of this subsection, in order to compute the orthogonal complement of a general subspace, usually it is best to rewrite the subspace as the column space or null space of a matrix.

statement.p:
Compute the orthogonal complement of the subspace
W = \bigl\{(x,y,z) \text{ in } \R^3\mid 3x + 2y = z\bigr\}.

solution.p:
Rewriting, we see that W is the solution set of the system of equations 3x + 2y - z = 0, i.e., the null space of the matrix A = \mat{3 2 -1}. Therefore,
W^\perp = \Row(A) = \Span\left\{\vec{3 2 -1}\right\}.
No row reduction was needed!

statement.p:
Find the orthogonal complement of the 5-eigenspace of the matrix
A = \mat{2 4 -1; 3 2 0; -2 4 3}.

solution.p:
The 5-eigenspace is W = \Nul(A - 5I_3) = \Nul\mat{-3 4 -1; 3 -3 0; -2 4 -2}, so
W^\perp = \Row\mat{-3 4 -1; 3 -3 0; -2 4 -2} = \Span\left\{\vec{-3 4 -1},\;\vec{3 -3 0},\;\vec{-2 4 -2}\right\}.
These vectors are necessarily linearly dependent (why)?

subsection.title: Row rank and column rank
subsection.p: Suppose that A is an m \times n matrix. Let us refer to the dimensions of \Col(A) and \Row(A) as the row rank and the column rank of A (note that the column rank of A is the same as the rank of A). The next theorem says that the row and column ranks are the same. This is surprising for a couple of reasons. First, \Row(A) lies in \R^n and \Col(A) lies in \R^m. Also, the theorem implies that A and A^T have the same number of pivots, even though the reduced row echelon forms of A and A^T have nothing to do with each other otherwise.

statement.p: Let A be a matrix. Then the row rank of A is equal to the column rank of A.

proof.p:
By the , we have
\dim\Col(A) + \dim\Nul(A) = n.
On the other hand the third fact says that
\dim\Nul(A)^\perp + \dim\Nul(A) = n,
which implies \dim\Col(A) = \dim\Nul(A)^\perp. Since \Nul(A)^\perp = \Row(A), we have \dim\Col(A) = \dim\Row(A), as desired.

subsection.p: In particular, by this both the row rank and the column rank are equal to the number of pivots of A.
